thread.title: Morning MoneyBeat Europe: Asian Data Continues To Disappoint
thread.title_full: Morning MoneyBeat Europe: Asian Data Continues To Disappoint

title: Morning MoneyBeat Europe: Asian Data Continues To Disappoint
text:
Please feel free to send this email to friends and colleagues and include this link so they can sign up to receive it for free too http://on.wsj.com/MoneyBeatEuropeSignup 
Follow us on Twitter @WSJMoneyBeat. 
European markets started on strong footing Tuesday, although Asian markets were a mixed bag after more disappointing data. 
Chinese exports fell in August for the second consecutive month as the world's second-largest economy continued its struggle to regain momentum. Customs said in a statement that China's exports will continue to face "relatively big pressure" in the fourth quarter. 
The Shanghai Composite Index recovered in the afternoon to close up 2.9%, lifting shares in Hong Kong by 2.4% and Australia up 1.7%. 
Japan's economy shrank at an annual pace of 1.2% in the April-June quarter from the prior three-month period, confirming the first contraction in three quarters, though the size of the decline was smaller than first thought. The Nikkei finished down 2.4%, its lowest level since February. 
Ahead in Europe, there isn't a huge amount of data due, but eurozone GDP due is expected to be un-revised at 0.3% on the quarter and 1.2% on the year. Trade data from Germany and France will be monitored. 
U.S. markets will reopen Tuesday, after staying closed Monday for the Labor Day holiday. 
-- Sarka Halas 
Market Snapshot: FTSE 100 up 1.51%, CAC 40 up 1.55% and DAX up 1.87%. Nikkei closed Tuesday down 2.43%. Brent crude up 0.73% at $47.98. Gold down 0.20% at $1119.20. EUR/USD at $1.1177. Ten-year Treasury yield higher at 2.15%, Bund yield higher at 0.68%, Gilt yield higher at 1.71%. 
What You May Have Missed on MoneyBeat 
On U.S. Rates Rise, Pace Matters More Than Timing — Strategists :Friday’s jobs report offered few fresh clues on the timing of a Federal Reserve’s rate increases, but strategists said Monday that pace still matters more than timing. 
These Hedge Funds Bucked Their Own Trend in August Selloff: Computer driven hedge funds have had a tough time over the past few months, but when the chips were down for global markets in late August, they came into their own. 
Glencore’s Big Move – The Numbers : Commodities giant Glencore PLC said Monday it would sell stock, scrap its dividend, suspend some mining operations and sell assets to reduce its net debt amid global market turmoil. 
Glencore Has Hedge Funds in Mind in Equity Sale: Why is Glencore raising $2.5 billion in equity? One reason: it should allow the miner and commodities trader to avoid offering shares to its existing investors, usually required by pre-emption rights under U.K. rules. 
Why the Euro Could Make Your Apple Upgrade Cost More: Apple Inc. is preparing to announce the launch of its new iPhones next week, but thanks to a stronger U.S. dollar, the company could raise prices in Europe by up to 15%, according to European investment bank Societe Générale. 
Gender Equality an ‘Economic No-Brainer,’ Says IMF Chief: International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde is pushing policymakers to get women into the world’s labor force. 
From The Wall Street Journal 
Migrant Wave Inspires Others to Attempt Trek to Europe: Stories and images of migrants pouring into Europe are inspiring thousands more, from Iraq to Nigeria, to rush out on their own risky journeys, posing a burgeoning problem for policy makers who are focused mainly on easing the plight of Syrian refugees. 
Glencore, Battered Mining Giant, Retreats: Collapsing commodity prices have forced one of the mining world’s most aggressive chief executives into retreat, pushing Glencore’s Ivan Glasenberg to scrap the company’s dividend, issue more stock and sell assets. 
Splits Plague Both Parties as Fall Primary Campaign Starts: The 2016 White House race barrels into the fall feeling at times more like a reality-television spectacle than a presidential campaign, with a crop of unconventional candidates upstaging their politically pedigreed rivals. 
Bank of America Pushes to Keep Moynihan’s Dual Role: Stung by a wave of investor criticism, Bank of America is stepping up efforts to convince shareholders that Chief Executive Brian Moynihan should remain chairman. 
San Francisco Fed’s Williams Sees Rate Increase ‘This Year,’ If Risks Dissipate: John Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, won’t say whether rate increases at the Fed’s Sept. 16-17 meeting are now in order. Instead, he sounds like a man on the fence. 
Corporate Prosecution Deals Headed for a Legal Test: A federal appeals court is set to decide whether judges can tear up corporate prosecution agreements they deem too lenient, in a case that Justice Department officials fear will disrupt the agency’s deals with companies under criminal investigation. More from The Wall Street Journal
